title: 103_s2471
content: The Act may be cited as the "Juvenile Corrections Act of 1994" and includes grants for violent and chronic juvenile facilities. The "Juvenile Corrections Act of 1994" allows the Administrator to provide grants to States and local governments for secure facilities for violent and chronic juvenile offenders. Eligibility follows the mandates of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Act. Applications for grants must be submitted by the chief executive officer of the State or local government, ensuring funded facilities meet specified criteria. The "Juvenile Corrections Act of 1994" allows grants for educational, vocational, and substance abuse treatment for incarcerated juveniles. Facilities funded must offer post-release supervision. Qualifying States must receive a minimum allocation of funds each fiscal year. Performance evaluation components are outlined. Each facility funded under the "Juvenile Corrections Act of 1994" must have an evaluation component with outcome measures to assess program effectiveness in reducing recidivism. The Administrator will review grant recipient performance and may require reports. The Administrator may request grant recipients to submit evaluation results and necessary data. Technical assistance and training may be provided by the Director of the National Institute of Corrections and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons. Definitions in this section include the Administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Programs. Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Programs define "Qualifying State" and "State" as entities eligible for grant applications. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 1996-2000 is specified. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 1996-2000 under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to allocate specific amounts for each year: $675,000,000 for 1996, $900,000,000 for 1997, $1,710,000,000 for 1998, $1,800,000,000 for 1999, and $1,863,000,000 for 2000.
